bioghist.p: Joseph Octave Delepierre (1804-1879) was a Belgian historian and diplomat. He studied law and practiced in Brussels before joining the diplomatic service. In 1849, he was appointed Consul-General of Belgium at London. He published on a range of subjects, including history, ancient literature, national bibliography, and archaeology.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscripts and correspondence of Octave Delepierre. Materials include: writings on literature, including his "Portefeuille d'un Bibliophile"; proverbs collected by Delepierre; translations by Delepierre, including George Varrentrapp's De l'emprisonnement individuel; a bibliography of works by and works edited by Delepierre; extracts from books and reading notes made by Delepierre; notes and essays on various subjects; and sketches on tracing paper. The collection includes a small number of letters; correspondents include: Ernest van Bruyssel, Felix-Victor Goethals, and M. L. Polain. Manuscripts are in French, English, and Latin.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
